instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR: What is PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR? PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR is PPBUS_G3H after it has passed through a backlight fuse and a transistor that allows power through when BKLT_PLT_RST_L and LCD_BKLT_EN are present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I have a backlight issue on an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. backlight Fuse was blown. Replaced fuse, stayed good after power on, no short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> line

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is 0.44V. 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_FUSED</SIGNAL>  is 12.57V
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> is 12.6V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR</SIGNAL> is (minus) -0.153V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> is 3.32V

<RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> is good
<RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> is good

System powers on and starts to boot so I am not sure what is causing no voltage on  <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>.

Please help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: OK. I just measured pin one of LVDS connector and its shorted to ground. Looks like I'm taking apart this display! Hopefully its just a cable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Is that short present only when LCD is connected?
If yes, then try another LCD assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Short to ground on pin 1 of LVDS cable.

- Disassembled Display and removed LVDS cable
- Observed corrosion in and around the connector and pin 1 on the cable end
- Replaced LVDS connector on display
- Replaced cable

Fixed
